Favorite quotes from Jellicoe Road:"Is a person worth more because they have someone to grieve for them?""That someone can want something out of another person who gives absolutely nothing in return astounds me." page 26"He has perfected the art of looking straight at someone while avoiding eye contact." page 81"He's not looking at me and suddenly I get why he doesn't look people in the eye. It's like he thinks he'll see the doubt or distrust or the questions about his past." page 224

It was difficult to get into, but worth the struggle. My question is what happend to Webb's body? Did I miss that somewhere in the book? If Fitz shot him out of the prayer tree, what did he do with the body?

I liked the writing. The story was interesting. I got tired of the "f" word used so often. There was a very cavalier attitude about teen sex and teen pregnancy. This book was heartbreaking in many spots, but I liked that the characters tried to look out for each other. There was a sweetness and innocence to the characters that I enjoyed. When the two main characters, Taylor and Griggs, had sex I was very disappointed and felt Taylor was making the same mistakes her mother made--too much commitment too young. I wish she had made a better choice. Teens deserve better morals in their literature. The story was compelling, though.

What a strange trip this book was. It rings like a bell somehow. There's some mystery not uncolored with horror, and some fabulous characterization. The plot arc is clean and relatively taut. On the other hand, there are some holes big enough to drive a postal van through. It's a book that communicates directly with the dark places in one's subconscious, one that has layers of meaning that have little to do with extraneous plot details. Disturbing and haunting. I'm glad I read it, but I'm not sure about the repercussions of its reverberations.

I was glad that I had some forewarning that the beginning of this book was confusing, because it was. However, it helps that the events in the past are mostly in italics because it makes it easier to go back and review once things start making sense. I don't really recall at what point things started to come together, but once they did I didn't want to put this book down. Excellent choice by the Printz committee.
Love it, love it, love it! Such a beautiful and moving novel. Intriguing story, fascinating characters and beautiful writing. No wonder it won the Printz. Just great.

I reread the first pages several times because I couldn't get acclimated time-wise or character-wise. I leaned into that sense of disorientation and immersed myself into the book, realizing that Marchetta would dole out info to readers on a "need to know" basis. That mystery and interconnection between two times, two sets of characters kept me on course and left me sad when the book ended. Ah, to leave them just when I was really getting to know and understand these people. . .
I ALMOST gave this 5 stars. Very very good.

A little confusing at first, but then that is part of the plot. Having to figure out a world of people, and how they connect is part the journey for Taylor as much as it is the reader. It will engulf you as you start to unravel the mysteries.

This book was amazing. I was a little bit frustrated when I began the book. I was tired and in the mood for a light read, and the book does not begin in a very straight-forward way. It mentions characters and events without introducing or explaining them, and it's confusing trying to make sense of everything. Also, Taylor, the main character, seemed sullen and purposefully impossible to like at the outset. However, I was quickly drawn in to the story, and looking back, there is no other way that the book could be written. By the time I really understood the meaning behind the events hinted at earlier in the book and the fates and histories of the characters, I had fallen in love with them and was desperate for things to turn out well. It is an incredible story.There is quite a bit of language and a lot of "adult themes," so even though it is listed as young adult fiction, I would hesitate to give it to even a high school student unless they were rather mature.

This was a great book, and a frustrating book! There are two different sets of characters, one group from the past, and a contemporary one, with no clues as to how they fit together, complicated by the fact that the characters' names are Australian and not obvious (at least to this American) which ones belong to boys, and which ones to girls. You learn right off that there was a car accident that brought five kids together in the past, and that there's a girl named Taylor trying to figure out what they have to do with her now. Fortunately, the plot is strong enough and rewarding enough to be worth it. I got to the end, and just as many other reviewers have said, immediately started again from the beginning.The main character is Taylor, a GIRL, and a student at the boarding school on Jellicoe Road. She's almost an orphan, and lives there year-round, since her mother left her at the age of nine. But Taylor knows there's a lot about her mother's life she doesn't know, and the READER knows it must have something to do with that other timeline. The hard part, the part that takes patience, is reading far enough into the book to find out how.In the meantime, the students of the boarding school are in a complicated wargame they play every year, with the townies and the cadets over territory, that is both fascinating and amusing. Adding to the fun, the intimidating leader of the cadets has a history with Taylor, leader of the students, and the leader of the townies has a history with Taylor's second in command, Raffaela. Oh! And there's a serial killer of kids lurking in the background of the story, too. Listen, just GO with it. Let yourself be confused while tearing through this puzzling yet engrossing book, and then once you have all the pieces, read the beginning again. It's worth it!
I've been listening to the audiobook this summer and I'm realizing this is my favorite YA book of all time. I've been thinking about it since Feb 2009. If that's not great art, I don't know what is.

All the cool kids are reading it...For the first ~150 pages or so, I had no idea what to make of this. I was confused, mildly intrigued but not hooked, but enjoying the writing enough that I plowed ahead. I'm glad I did, because once this starts coming together, it doesn't stop. Rich, dynamic characters, a couple of interwoven stories, and some beautiful writing--what more could you ask from a book?That said, it's not a book just any teen will pick up, but I can think of a few who would probably respond well to it.

Wow. This was one of the best stories I have read in a really long time. It took me a while to get into it, but once I did, I did not want to stop. When I first stared I thought it was a little weird and wondering if this was some post-apocalyptic thing or secret world thing or what. She was talking about Townies, Cadets, territory wars, initiations. I was thinking I was not going to be happy, but her writing style was so good that I kept on reading. Then I read my friend Shannon's review that said to give it a chance because it does get better. Man was she right. Eventually I discovered that it is a realistic situation and that this was a "game" to the kids and relationships started forming. There were 2 stories going on and eventually they started to link so then it became a question of figuring out who everyone was. Marchetta gives you just enough and you discover as Taylor discovers. It is such a beautifully written story about coming of age, deep seated prejudices, family connections, and the enduring power of love and friendship. So beautiful.
I love this book!!! So good...I cried. DEFINITELY READ THIS BOOK!!!

I wanted to dislike this book because it felt like another out-of-nowhere Printz pick and my favorite book of the year "Hunger Games" didn't even get an honor. However, I have to admit, it's really really good. I do think it has wide appeal to teen readers, if they chance to pick up a book by an unknown author with an ambiguous title.It's about a girl (Taylor) at a boarding-type school. Every year they have territory wars with the Townies and the Cadets, which is just getting started. Taylor is also struggling with a need to find her mother, who abandoned her when she was 11. That's about all I can say without revealing too much.I didn't give it 5 stars only because the beginning is very confusing. There is no explanation of what is going on, and the italicized memory/story/other monologue exacerbates the problem. However, if you can get through about 50 pages and start to get some idea of what's happening, you'll be hooked.
This book was phenomenal. Absolutely incredible to read. It took me a little bit to get into it but now I want to go back and reread it immediately.Very awesome.

I LOVE this book!!!! It has mystery, sadness, and romanticness all in one book!!!!!! altho it was hard for me 2 understand when I first started it, i tried again and loved it!!!! I couldn't put it down!!!!

I give this book 5 stars after page 130. The beginning was not particularly enthralling, but the story definitely evolved towards the end. I can see why some people may not enjoy this book- usually my favourites capture my attention in the first few pages. On The Jellicoe Road was definitely an exception to my rule. The second half of the book excused the slow beginning.The emotion in the book was so raw and touching. Once you understood the relationships and how everyone was linked, you could not help but be affected by the characters' stories. The story went in an opposite direction to what I was expecting by reading the first 100 or so pages. The plot seemed a bit silly and unemotional at the beginning, but it takes a quick change. I don't really want to go into the storyline, because it takes an unpredictable course. When I read this book I had no idea what to expect, and my confusion wasn't really resolved until I was half way into the story. I had many theories as to where the story would go, and most of them were way off. I advise reading this book with no previous knowledge of the plot. If a friend has spilled it to you, well what a shame. Although it was frustrating at the time, I'm glad I was left in the dark. This is by far Melina Marchatta's best work.

Eh. I read this book in little pieces, so as others have mentioned, the connection between the dual stories and all of the characters was a bit confusing in the beginning, and I really had trouble getting into it. For the sake of the Printz Award, I pushed through. The ending was OK and sufficiently wrapped up the story. It just didn't really knock my socks off.

wow. just wow. this book was incredible.i hated it for the first 100 or so pages to be honest, like many people have also said. but then everything starts making sense and everything falls into place and the revelation is incredible.this book is moving and incredible and constructed so intricately and perfectly that i ended up putting off a paper so i could finish the book instead, and it was so worth it.

Trigger warnings - references to sexual abuse of children.I really liked this, and I managed not to cry til the very end, mostly because I was in public. I want to give it a couple months to settle and then read it again now that I have all the names and things straight.

[Wow! This book was slow to start primarily because it took me a little time to reconcile the two parallel story lines. But once I figured out what was going on, I was hooked. This is an intense book. I'm still not sure if I understand everything.:]Taylor Markham assumes the leadership of her school in their yearly battle for territory with the Townies and the Cadets. Her dealings with these 2 groups bring her back into contact with her past. Through her friend's novel manuscript, Taylor discovers the story of 5 teens on Jellicoe Road 18 years ago. The past meets the present as Taylor finds out who she is.What I thought: This was an intense, intriguing book. I admit that I almost didn't finish it as I was confused for the 1st 30 pages or so. After I sorted out the 2 separate yet connected story lines, I was able to read with more ease. Even now, I'm not sure I understand all that happened in the book.
It was too dis-jointed for me--strong ending, but I really had to push to keep reading.
The story of a girl desperate to find out about her past and the slow unfolding of the tale of her parents and her life. Very emotional story.

The twists and turns of this book were predictable to me, but I think it's because I recognized similarities to characters in Finnikin of the Rock and especially Froi of the Exiles, both by Marchetta. I appreciated the depth and artistry of Marchetta's writing, but Jellicoe did not hold life-changing revelation for me, other than to be this densely beautiful piece of art.

Wow - I must admit, I probably wouldn't have picked this book up had it not won the Printz award. This sure is good stuff! It is mysteriously engaging and has a pace that I can't quite explain and the plot is multi-layered and difficult. It wasn't until about 200 pages in that I started to figure out what was going on. But, I appreciated that the author sort of let the story unfold slowly and meaningfully both for the reader and for Taylor, the protagonist. The story of love, loss, and memory is written so well and hits those themes dead-on with such passion and feeling. It reminded me of other similar books that I like very much: The God of Small Things by Arundhati Roy and How I Live Now by Meg Rosoff. Very, very good!

This was an amazing book! The beginning was kind of irritating to read because I didn't get what was going on, but it makes the book better because you get bits and pieces of the puzzle when you continue to read.
Another boarding school book, but not like other boarding school books. Two stories are intertwined and the reader pieces them together as the main characters do.
Kind of confusing at first, but it all comes together in the end. Great book about the struggle of a teenage girl to discover her past. I found it very entertaining.

It took quite a while to figure out what was going on, but once it came together I couldn't put it down. And the obscurity at the beginning assisted it putting the reader in the head of the narrator. It was a lovely unfolding.

This book confused me for the first 50 pages or so. I ended up skipping over all the flashbacks because I had no idea what they were of or what they were trying to tell me. However, I soon got into the book and could not put it down. It was so brutally honest, yet sweet and resonating. The story was beautifully and hauntingly written, and I would recommend this to everyone.
This is down the list somewhat: I want to read "Saving Francesca" first, for example. But I *love* "Alibrandi" and I've been meaning to read Marchetta's other works /sometime/...

Just like The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks, I just don't get why this won the Printz Award (I know, I know- the former was an Honor award). Oh yeah, it has orphans... It was good, but it took a long time to get into it. Might appeal to a few mature, female young adults.

This is the 2009 Printz Award, the Teen equivalent of the Newbery Award. It was published in Australia a couple of years ago and was published last year in the U.S. Well, I must say, the Aussies are becoming my new favorite group of authors (Zusak, Shusterman, to name two). I loved the voice and the story kept me very intrigued, but my rating is a little lower than it could have been because as I was reading, I kept hearing my daughter's constant criticism of teen books that adults love. I teased her when I was reading it, saying, "You'll love this book." She responded as sarcastically as I asked, "Why because it's full of dysfunctional families, drugs and missing mothers." "Exactly!" That's basically what this book is about, but, to its credit, it is well done and has an element of mystery to it. It is about 5 friends who lived near Jellicoe Road years ago contrasted with a group of students, townies, and cadets who live there now. Their stories become connected and over time, the obscure passages told from the past become more and more clear. It definitely kept me turning the pages.

It most certainly takes a patience reading and for a moment that wasn't me. After 200+ pages I liked the book and when I finished the book I really appreciated the first 200 pages. Also it had the best "book kiss" I've read in awhile.

WARNING: There are 2 sex scenes in this book.Taylor has been at the Jellicoe School longer then anybody else. It still comes as a surprise when the departing Seniors put her in charge of the Territory War. Jellicoe School, set in the outback of Australia, is in a constent secret battle between the Townies and the Cadets. Taylor must mack sure she doesn't lose any territory, and if possiable gain some back from the Townies.Everything spirals out of control for Taylor when her long time counselor Hannah leaves her suddenely, and the head of the Cadets turns out to be the person who betrayed her 3 years ago.I LOVED THIS BOOK. I do however think it got pegged as a Teen book because it's set in HIgh School, but these Teens are like no Teens I've ever met. I think if you liked White Oleander, you'll enjoy this book as well. I laughed, I cried, I walked away disgusted. It bounces around in my brain. I want the story to go on with Taylor, Griggs, Ben, Chez, and Raffy. I want happiness for all of them.

when i was younger, i used to write these series of stories about kids with no parents who lived in boarding schools and had dramatic relationships. it was really nice to see someone write it SO MUCH BETTER! couldn't put this book down, totally retract my haterade for it getting the printz over the disreputable history of frankie landeau-banks.
It was a good mystery, but not entirely satisfying to me. Review on my blog: http://librariansbookreviews.blogspot...

I actually had to take out a notebook and pen to sort out all the characters and what was going on. In the end it all comes together quite nicely. Australian setting had a few terms and words that were unfamiliar to an American, but I believe it earned the Michael Printz medal this year. Funny how that's the second M.P. award winner I've read that is set in a boarding school.
As soon as I finished it, I read it again. Then I read my favorite parts a third time.

This book won the Printz Award (young adult version of the Newbery Award) this year. It is carefully crafted and emotionally powerful. The book came out in Australia in 2006, and the US edition (titled Jellicoe Road, having dropped the On the) was published in 2008. Taylor Markham, the seventeen-year-old protagonist, is in charge of her house at her Boarding school. She is struggling to remember and piece together her past, having been abandoned at the school six years earlier by her mother. A parallel story provides her (and the reader) with disjointed clues as to events that began twenty years ago with a horrendous car accident, and where and how the survivors fit in Taylor's life. Try not to let the confusion put you off in the beginning - it reminds me a bit of Time Traveler's Wife, in that I had to "let go" and just keep reading - and was ultimately very glad I did.
Eh, I don't know, it isn't bad, but it hasn't really sucked me in yet. Maybe if I sat down and paid attention it might.
An interesting tale with many twists.

Sort of a slow starter for me - the jumps between the past and present were a little confusing at first, until I caught on to who the characters were. The book definitely finished strong, and I'm anxious to read Marchetta's earlier works, now.
Can't wait...heard great things!

A good one but a bit difficult to follow at times. Much better than last year's Printz winner but I still think they could choose books that were a little more accessible to the general teen population - I think this wouldn't work for most readers.
The Printz Medal winner 2009. The plot is confusing at first because it has 2 intertwining stories that end up being the same story. I was totally confused through about the first half of the book.

“I am the holder of grief and pain and guilt and passion of Jonah Griggs and as we sit huddled on the floor of the carriage, he allows me to hold him, to say, ‘Shhh, Jonah, it wasn’t your fault.’ While his body still shakes from the convulsions, he takes hold of my hand and links my fingers with his and I feel someone else’s pain for the first time that I can remember.” Jellicoe Road is by far the most confusing book I’ve read in recent memory. It’s also the most rewarding. After being held hostage by the king of all hooks in the prologue (“My father took 132 minutes to die. I counted...”), I expected the plot to unfold quickly thereafter. Instead, the mysterious plot slowly inched forward by cleverly moving backward. This story shares the lives of a group of downtrodden, neglected teenagers – many wards of the state – attending the Jellicoe School out in the “boondocks.” Since so few have parents in their lives, they come to depend highly on one another. Teenagers in the town have created territories and proclaimed war against opposing groups. In addition to dealing with territory disputes, seized hostages and keeping the girls of her house safe, Taylor Markham is struggling to contain the demons of her miserable past, unstable present and unpredictable future. At seemingly every turn, she finds battles to fight, drama to tame and an unlikely romance to decipher. But Taylor’s biggest distraction is trying to solve the painful mysteries of her past. Melina Marchetta has written an absolute masterpiece. Appreciating this story requires an extremely patient reader who is willing to reread confusing parts several times over. Marchetta challenges her readers to make higher-level connections most authors wouldn’t dare try in fear of losing their readers too soon. You may find yourself completely lost 200 and even 300 pages into this story but stick it out to the end. The book is like a puzzle with 419 pieces. Each piece of the page (i.e., each page) must be carefully considered and pieced together in the correct context in order to be fully understood. As you make it toward the end of the book, you will recall scenes throughout the story that previously had you wondering, “What in the world is going on?” and you will say aloud, “Oooohhh!! I get it now. WOW!” When, late in the story, the author began dropping subtle clues to make sense of earlier scenes, my eyes continually widened and my jaw constantly dropped - and my heart even pounded at times! Once completed, you will experience a moving story that will force you to break out the tissues and to applaud Marchetta’s brilliant storytelling. Jellicoe Road is oftentimes devastating, sometimes humorous and steadily mysterious. It is an intricate, complicated story that could easily be used as part of a college-level literature course. I decided to read the book because I came across Jellicoe Road as I was trying to find good books to read on Goodreads. I noticed Jellicoe Road scored a high rating on Goodreads, so I gave it a try. While a select handful of 8th graders might be able to tackle and interpret this story, I would recommend this story mainly for advanced avid readers, high school and above. (419 pages)

I was incredibly confused in the beginning of this book, but kept on anyway. I'm so glad I did. Taylor Markham's character was so well developed that by the end of the book I was almost going crazy hoping that things would "work out"...as well as they can when so many people in her life had already died. I completely fell in love with the boy she fell in love with along with her. The story within a story enchanted me completely. This book is definitely for sophisticated teens who can handle the necessary development in the beginning of the book.

"I remember asking, 'What's the difference between a trip and a journey?' and my father said 'Narnie, my love, when we get there, you'll understand,' and that was the last thing he ever said."This quote taken from this book completely captures my feelings as I read this book. I felt that I was taken on an unforgettable journey. It has been a long time since I was so drawn and so captivated by a book that I felt as though I knew and loved the characters in the story. I was so immersed into their world and their grief that for a time it became my own.This story does have a rather confusing beginning. But by the time I hit chapter three, there was no way I could not not finish reading this book. In fact I read until 3:30am because I couldn't put it down. I am very stingy with my ratings, but this book is well deserving of its 5 stars.
A little too dramatic for me, but a good read. The insight of the girl was good, but the drama just keeps going until the end.
Marchetta tells good stories, but do they have to be so sad? I also figured out the mystery of most of the book halfway through, but it was still very good!

4Q 3P JSTaylor Markham is a senior at a boarding school in Australia. She does not know much about her past and only has a few scattered memories of her early childhood. When she was eleven, her mother abandoned her at a gas station and a woman who lives next to her school picked her up and brought her to the school. Taylor knows that Hannah has some connection to her past, and worries when she disappears without letting Taylor know where she is going or when she will be back. While Taylor worries about her mysterious past and Hannah’s location, she is also supposed to be leading her school in the annual territory wars between the townies and visiting cadets. She is also perplexed by unsettling dreams and a story about five friends who used to go to her school. Can Taylor figure out her past and not let her school down? Or will she cave under the stress?Like many people have said, this book begins slowly, but picks up as the novel progresses and the storylines start coming together. I think that the characters and plot could be appealing to some teens, particularly those who like a challenge and appreciate lots of description. Many of the teens in this book have experienced much loss and have lots of pain to deal with. Reading about these characters could help teens learn to empathize with other people and see the world from another person’s perspective.

I loved this book and would have given it 5 stars except that it didn't fully grab me until about 100 pages in. Initially, I was completely confused, and disinterested in the territory wars, but finally the pieces began falling into place and I raced through the second half. Marchetta has a knack for dialogue and showing intense emotion, and I loved how the dual narratives ultimately came together with healing and hope.

Taylor was abandoned on the Jellico Road when she was 11 years old. She was taken in my Hannah, a caretaker at the Jellico School, a place for wards of the state to go to school until they are 18. Behind the seeming quiet of Jellico School is a feud that goes back before Taylors time there, a secret war going on between the students of Jellico School, the townies and the cadets. Taylor has just been named the leader of the students and it is hear job to regain precious territory from the cadets and townies. Taylor is surprised to find out that her enemy, the leader of the cadets, is the same boy she ran away with when she was 14. When Hannah disappears, Taylor decides to try to unravel the mystery around Hannah, her mother and the hermit. Enemies become unexpected friends when the leaders of the townies and cadets help Taylor in her search.I was super confused when I started reading this book, it really needs a map and a character guide. Because they refer to several people by their last names, I couldn't even keep track of who was a guy and who was a girl. But after about 200 pages I really got into it. I can see why it won the award. It was a beautiful book with some unexpected twists.

Worthy of the Printz Award? Get past the 1st 100 pages of the book, let the story and all it's pieces and complexities gel in your thoughts...and ,yes, it's a book that deserves the accolades. You won't soon forget these characters.

It took me forever to read this book (because it kept getting interrupted by others I had to read), so I feel a little disconnected from it for that reason. Our heroine Taylor is tough, a bit prickly, and yet vulnerable. Honestly, what kept me going was the mystery surrounding her intense relationship with her should-be enemy, Jonah Griggs. I found the side-plot/interruptions by Hannah's writing to be a tad annoying and yet compelling. I kept forgetting the second story's characters, and when I was just wanting to read about Taylor, the damn second plot would interrupt. So, despite the fact that I just rattled off things I dislike, I thought the book was interesting with good characters. Definitely would NOT have given the Printz to this book over Hunger Games--TRAVESTY!

I'm still thinking about the annotation. Apparently I started reading this 22 days ago. That's when I read the first two chapters and thought "Nope, can't do this" and shifted it aside to stare at for three weeks. I came back, but with a grumble.It's frustrating and purposely ambiguous for at least 200 pages; the confusing doesn't go away and only lets up enough to give you a few clues. No one ever explains what's going on* and it's set in an unrealistic and unbelievable high school situation ("wars" for territory of trails, buildings, etc between townies, cadets, and the leader of the six houses of a boarding school which in itself seems unlikely and unrealistic) where no one goes to class. Even by the end, you know you need to reread it all to fully get what happened. So, in other words, a perfect candidate for a Printz, no?*Which yes, I get, is the point since Taylor has no damn clue herself but a little background would have made a difference.I didn't like the bits between chapters, even after I figured out what they were and that I shouldn't have been skimming them. Sometimes in a book, these sorts of breaks are nice but here they caused an ugh! and a flipping to see how many pages I had to get through.BUT - and this is an all caps worthy but - by the end, I really liked it.Here's the thing: I was mad at the book but I wanted to keep reading. I couldn't tell you exactly when, but you'll reach a shift where you stop reading just to plow through and start reading because you don't want to put it down. You've just got to be willing to stick with it long enough to make that happen.The massive mystery unwinds slowly but, and you've got to trust me here, it's worth it. There's a large cast of characters to keep track of, but (again after 200 pages) Taylor, Griggs, Raffaela, and Santangelo pull away and you don't feel so lost. Maybe the point I'm trying to make is that while the reading experience is having lots of pieces thrown at you, Marchetta's a good enough writer to hold it all together. A note on stars / recommendation / ages:Firmly between 4-5 stars, if you keep reading. I'd happily reread the second half, no doubtRecommendations are tough. It's worth recommendations but not for all patron and maybe a "stick with it" kind of comment should be included.Also - the Horn Book said 12-14. Roger Sutton, I adore you, but you're crazy. I can't imagine that's where most readers will fall. I'd say 10th on up--not because it's inappropriate for middle school (albeit dark at times in plot and topics) but because it's a text that requires some work and effort to get through. Plus, the main characters (one set, anyway) are for all practical purposes hs seniors.

This fascinating novel deserves the Printz award. I thought it was unnecessarily confusing at the beginning but it all made sense as one read on. The relationships and secrets between a few characters did not seem realistic but it was a gripping read.

Sorry JB, but this book DID NOT deserve to win the Printz. Not when it was up against Tender Morsels, Octavian Nothing: Kingdom on the Waves, and The Disreptuable History of Frankie Landau-Banks (which should have won instead). Jellicoe Road is beautifully written, and the characters are well-drawn and full of life, BUT it was full of way too many realistic teen fiction cliches (abandoned teens, boarding school skirmishes, ultimate romance between bitter rivals, and so on). Also, the connections between the past and present narratives become apparent pretty early on, and then the plot becomes rather predictable. It was a good book, and I don't regret reading it, but it didn't blow me away like Frankie Landau-Banks did.
very deserving of the Printz Award. I'm glad I wasn't on the committee, trying to decide between this, Hunger Games, and Frankie Landau-Banks.

Jellicoe Road is the Printz award winner. It takes a long time to understand what this story is all about. It is worth it by the end, and I am glad I read this. Two families have a head on collision on the highway. Their lives then become tangled and intwined for years and several generations. Life isn't easy for any of them and in the end they realize that they have needed eachother all along. The characters realize they are dependant on one another to survive and care about each other. The kids have been spared from the history and details to try to spare them from the agony of hurt and loss. The kids then have a sense of loss and mystery. They try to find out as much as they can on their own. By banding together in their loss and craziness at the house and camp for wayward boys and girls, who don't have a home, on Jellicoe road, they develop friendships that will last a lifetime. The girls are there year round. The boys only come in for summer camp across the river. The kids have had a tradition of territory wars. This was developed as a way to interact and have fun together. The kids create some close relationships that make me wish I could have experienced all the fun. The kids are recovering from horrible experiences but they come together to create a hope and love. What a beautiful story. VOYA quality is a 5. VOYA popularity 3. I don't think many kids will stick through this book long enough to make it to the good part. The kids in this story were able to give eachother some of the development assets that they need to become a healty adult. Most of the family life missing for the kids was given to them by the relationships they formed with each other. The kids were able to go to a place where solid rules were in place. The camp rules were strict and the territory rules were also very strict and thorough. Many times the older kids were expected to care for the younger ones. And although all of the characters had obvious needs that were not getting met. They were able to support eachother through the pain and lacking.

I started reading Jellicoe Road about two weeks ago. I got through the first 122 pages. I was drawn in, I was curious and plotting out the characters. I was caught a little off guard at first in the two stories being told. So when I put the book down I kept thinking about it. I wasn't able to pick it up again until last night. I read from about 2:00 am until 5:30 am. I couldn't stop. I complete understand why it won the Printz this year. I loved this book. Sometimes after reading an especially moving and amazing book, I will hold it for a few minutes after I finish. It is my way of thanking it. I don't do this with many books, maybe a few dozen or less in all of my years reading. I thanked this book last night. Jellicoe Road is such a beautiful and haunting story. It is so full of tragedy and loss and hope and love. I felt the characters heartbreak, their sadness, I also felt there joy. When Taylor describes the joy she sees on Webb's face I smiled with him. I hope anyone who was on the fence about reading it, gives it a try, I don't think you will regret it.

Over all I did really like this book, but the "hook" as they say, didn't appear (at least for me) until page 235, and then I felt I figured out the story by page 243.Strong teen readers will likely keep at this book, but reluctant readers will likely give up.It is truly a wonderful work of literature, and as such and I am pleased that it was the winner of the Printz Award for Young Adult Fiction.

An excellent book that manages to defy genres and my ability explain what happens. It's complicated, with a slowly unfolding family mystery that requires a rereading once you get to the end. It is adventurous, fun, and even occasionally romantic and funny. Set in Australia at a boarding school with a bizarre histoy of holding border wars, which ends up playing a key part in the mystery surrounding Taylor's family, Jessa's family, Hannah's family, and the school on Jellicoe Road.The only draw back is every time I saw the word "Jellicoe", the stupid "Jellico Cats" song from the musical Cats started playing in my head and I don't know how the song ends, so it played endlessly! Grrr.

This one's hard ... it was really well written, quite beautiful, strong characters, and good coming-of-age story ... however, it's totally, utterly confusing until you get into Chap 3 - around pg 40!!! The author should have given a clue that the italicized portions (which start the story & intersperse it) are a story one of the characters is writing -- your head is swimming with all these names, and more names, and more names. And on top of that, duelling story lines are going, with the reader just plunked right down in the middle of all this history. All that said, I do recommend it, but it has to be done with explanation, and to someone who really loves to read - will stay with it until it starts making sense and getting good.

This is, without question, the best book I've read so far this year. Yes, it was initially confusing--who are these people with the story in italics, and what do they have to do with Taylor?--but it has a most satisfying ending.

The writing is a little confusing at first. The voice switches from a story written by a character to another character's perspective. I liked the story plot; it seemed a little far fetched at times. The main character is extremely likable and has the moody teenager thing down perfectly. I am not sure that it is so wonderful that it is a must read for teenagers.

I was only going to give this book a 4, but then I kept thinking more and more about it and it bumped it up to a 4.5-5 or so...Anyway, a great YA fictional book. It took me about 20 (short) pages to get into it before I started to get a feel for the disjointed narrative (present, past memories, a manuscript/journal from the past as well). But then I loved it. It's a story filled with such hope and redemption that it overcomes all the sorrow you feel in the middle for these tough lives and kids. Even though the characters are all 17, they have lived through such difficult things in the past that they are all mature beyond their years, so it wasn't juvenile reading in any way. They also have their good share of pranks and fun things that reminded me of good old high school days. I'm really glad I read it!!!!

I picked up this book after learning it won the Newbery Award for young adult fiction this year. It was a mixed bag. The first half was too all over the place, introducing too many characters and not focusing enough on Taylor (the main character), consequently I didn't really "care" about what happened to her. Things really shaped up in the second half, Marchetta got more into the character development and the story sucked me in. By the end of the book, I was a fan. : )

I have tried reading this book before now, but just wasn't in the right place to read it (too many other books, after the first chapter I thought it would be too depressing)....after reading her fantasy series, I knew that I would like anything by this author and gave it another go. I ended up loving this book! It is one of those books that is sad to finish...I wanted to know these people for a few more days. I was literally mad at myself for finishing it so fast, and kept reading random parts just to keep it alive. Disclaimer: This writer is Australian...which means what? I'd like to believe that in Australia our swear words are not as "bad" as they are here :-) There is a lot of swearing...but it didn't bother me (I blame it on riding the bus with "country" kids for WAY too many years) I found this book in the Young Adult section...and I thought that it leaned toward the Adult part of Young.
I got bored. Skimmed.

This is one of those books that seems to capture all the loneliness and longing of teenage years but in a way that makes you feel for the characters rather than be annoyed by them. It took me a bit to get into the way the storyline flows, but once I figured it out I loved how it was written.

I thought I would be excited about this book, since it won the Printz. However, by page 100 I gave up! It's hard to understand, as the story is set in Australia (and the language is odd in many places), and the characters are just flat, boring and had to follow. The author doesn't explain anything, and it's just a confusing jumble of events and flashbacks. I am shocked this won, re-reading Looking For Alaska right now--that's a title that desverd it's award. I'd love to chat with someone who like Jellicoe Road.

There's a few books on my shelf that I can read over and over again. But I have to say, this is one of them.In true Marchetta style, the complex characters provide a heart-wrenching story across two timelines. For as long as Taylor has been in Jellicoe, three things have been certain. First, she will eventually be leader at the Jellicoe School in Year 11 in the war against the Townies and Cadets. Two, Hannah lives in the house by the river and always will. Three, Hannah has been writing a manuscript about five best friends.Then Hannah disappears.Taylor's world turns upside down--her rock is gone, she's finding friends in places she never thought she would, and the manuscript haunts her.What should be a fun, end-of-school, coming of age book turns into so much more under Marchetta's deft hand; the emotion, the love and the work that has been put into this book (fourteen years in the making) is evident with each word. Marchetta puts on paper exactly what every one of us wants to feel. "Belong. Long to be."

Must read book that beat Paper Towns._____Books don't get much better than this. It pulls at your heartstrings. The writing flows well and I could barely put it down. I miss the characters already, sad to say. I wish I'd read this book sooner, I've known about it forever. It definitely deserved its award.

A really phenomenal book - 4.5 stars. Nothing like Finnikin of the Rock, which is a fantasy. Jellicoe Road takes place in our world, in the present day (or close enough to it). Marchetta is a fantastic writer and her books have none of the melodrama that really annoys me about teen books sometimes. She is definitely one of my new favorite authors.

A group of teens bond while partaking in a cruel tradition of territory wars between boarding schoolers, townies, and visiting cadets. Eventually the story of the first teens who devised these "games" is uncovered, providing answers which help heal protagonist Taylor's shattered life. (But Taylor suffers tremendously due to a lot of seemingly unnecessary secrecy about her past! And why isn't she getting counseling?!!) Marchetta's writing is described as "heartfelt" on the dust jacket. Sure, there is love and redemption, but the story's violence, angst and unlawfulness overshadowed that for me, and I still feel raw from it all. (Why couldn't the cat have been painlessly euthanized? Why did Ben's fingers have to be broken? Why the whole fire scene, and the jocular attitude about arson?) After also reading "The Chocolate War", "Catcher in the Rye", and "Looking for Alaska" all in the past year, I've had my full share of boarding school hell, but I forced myself to read past the first few chapters of "On the Jellicoe Road" because this book received the Printz Award--I wanted to find its merits. I personally did not enjoy the edgy tone, but the story's layers of narrative are indeed cleverly wrought. The suspense is gripping, the friendships memorable. And there are probably deeper themes about Australia that elude me. The original gang of five (as well as Taylor's new group of friends) can represent the different cultural ancestry of Australia--their pain, warfare and friendships represent the nation's history and its hope. In that way, I would also compare this book to "A Separate Peace", one that I could not fully understand and appreciate as a teen until it was carefully taught in school. This book, however, is much more graphic.

Another great YA read. At first I got really confused between the "past" and "present" and the connections between them. I also had difficulty keeping the 5 characters from the past straight--they all had unisex names and that was confusing. But about half-way through it sucked me in and I really enjoyed it. The mystery of the connections between characters now and in the past and trying to figure it out made it a great read. The romance was really well done.
This is the newest Prinz winner. I liked it, but the confusion of the first fifty pages or so takes some patience to wade through.

This was different from most things that I read, and it took me awhile to get into it, but in the end, it was a decent read.Warning for those who object to rough language -- this one uses some offensive language.
Really enthralling, not predictable because of the unique non-linear style. Loved it.
After reading this I wanted to go back and re-rate all my other books. Or perhaps give this a "6".

I loved, loved, LOVED this author's first two books, and this one was great, too. Even though it is a young adult book, I think any reader would enjoy it. It tells a story of a teenager who was abandoned by her mother and the trouble she has dealing with her lack of history, while at the same time giving clues about a group a kids who lived in the same town years before that are somehow connected to this girl. It creates a sort of mystery-feeling that helps move the story along, and there are a couple spots that need the push to get past the angsty-teenager pages. I see that in this book as well as the author's previous books that most of the problems for her teenage protagonists, the thing that sends them over the edge and makes all the adults suddenly worry and pay attention, is that they aren't told all the information. The adults around them, trying to "protect them," hide information. The teenagers want the answers, especially this character who doesn't know who she is or where she came from. And when you're at an age where you're trying to define who you are, not knowing is a big deal. Worth running away and getting in trouble over.My only issue with this book is that that tragedies seem a bit over the top, the people a little too damaged, but it's worth over-looking that minor flaw.

I had a hard time getting into this book. I couldn't get into the school/campus wars. The best part of the book was Narnie's stories. I would have like to have more Narnie, Webb, Tate, Jude, and Fitz. I pushed through. I was anxious to see how Taylor's life was connected to those 5.The ending was well worth the wait. It was filled with love, emotion, and loads of togetherness. Would I recommend? Only if you can hold off until about 100-150 pages. It doesn't start to get interesting until then. (Looking at other reviews, I don't seem to be alone in this.) The ending is definitely worth the wait.

Taylor is the head of her house at the Jellicoe boarding school and she’s the head of the school in the territory wars between the school, the Townies, and the Cadets. Taylor ran away from school 3 years ago when she was 14 (with one of the Cadets – Jonah Griggs) to try and find her mother who abandoned her at a 7-11 when she was just a little girl. Taylor’s been wondering about her family and her past for as long as she can remember, and this year things come to a head when her guardian, Hannah, disappears for several weeks to take care of some “personal” business, and leaves Taylor alone and frustrated. Taylor and the leaders of the Cadets and Townies become close friends, as the leaders once were back when the territory wars started. And it’s Jonah, again, who accompanies Taylor when she sets off – this time to track down Hannah – in search of the truth.This is really two stories woven together - Hannah’s story about her past, and Taylor’s story about her present. They’re remarkably similar – with young people who come to be friends and then more than friends, who invent and play a game just so they can spend more time together, and who have a shared history. In Hannah’s story, however, there’s a terrible tragedy that affects the lives of all the others and continues to have effects years later. It’s what makes Taylor’s mom turn to drugs so she can forget, what makes her abandon Taylor, what makes Hannah keep a distance from the people she loves, and what eventually brings the survivors back together again. This is all about the friendships forged and the unraveling mystery of Taylor’s and Hannah’s past. I really like Melina Marchetta’s writing, she creates realistic characters and situations and stories with depth.
Okay, so maybe there was another book from 2008 better than Frankie Landau-Banks. To superficially simplify things, that one delighted my head while this one hit me in the gut.
I have been reading a lot of good YA this year, it seems, probably due to Navah's influence. I was hooked from the very first line.

Marchetta captures the complexity of human relationships in a way that is compelling and and memorable.Due to the language and subject matter, this book would be best for mature teens or adults--preferrably to read and discuss together.

An intensely emotional rollercoaster ride of a book.One that starts out a little on the confusing side. There are so many things going on in this book it was hard to keep them straight. There is Taylor Markham, abandoned by her mother when she was 11, her father has never been around and she doesn't know why, her guardian Hannah has left town without telling her, a boy from her past is back in town and getting under her skin. Then there are the territory wars between the townies, the cadets and the students of the Jellico school, a boarding school of which she is their reluctant leader.And then there is the back story which pops up intermitently throughout the book about 5 kids who lived on the Jellicoe Road over 20 years ago, 3 of whom were involved in a terrible accident that killed 5 people. This part confused me at first because I could not figure out how the story of those 5 kids had any relevance at all to the present situation and I kept feeling like I was missing some crucial plot element, but when the pieces start to fall together like pieces in a puzzle it is so worth the wait. Each detail of this story has some relevance and each piece that falls into place is like a revelation. Once things start to come together I had a hard time putting it down and am still thinking about even now.Ultimately this is a book about a girl who is desperate to put together the pieces of her past and find where she belongs. It is a heartbreaking story and yet it is also one of hope and love.There are definitely undertones of some mature subject matter; death, drug addiction, abuse, suicide, and a brief sex scene so I would not recommend it to younger readers or anyone really who would be bothered by that, but definitely a story that made an impression on me.
I loved this one. Completely and totally.
Wonderful, wonderful! I was lying in bed sobbing after I finished this book; partly because of the story, and partly because I was sad it was finished.
I did not want this book to end! I felt like I knew the characters personally and was rooting for each one--even the ones from the past--to find happiness.

Yep everyone right, this one was slightly confusing for the first hundred pages or so. I kept wondering if that was the authors way of creating some mystery because, while I really liked the book, it was pretty obvious what was going on and who was who. I loved the relationships, and since that's primarily what the book was about, I enjoyed it.

A few months ago I predicted on my blog that Paper Towns (2008) would be receiving a nod from the Printz committee at the 2009 awards ceremony. Failing that, I was certain that after nabbing a National Book Award, What I Saw and How I Lied (2008) would take a Printz award/honor.You can therefore imagine my surprise when it was neither of my predicted titles but Melina Marchetta's Jellicoe Road* (2008**) that won the 2009 Printz Award for excellence in young adult literature. Being a fan of Marchetta's previous novels Looking for Alibrandi (1992) and especially Saving Francesca (2005) you can also imagine my embarrassment upon realizing one of my favorite authors had published a new book without my realizing it.The only solution, of course, was to immediately procure a copy from the library and read it as soon as possible.Jellicoe Road is not a novel with one protagonist. Rather, it has many. The story starts on the Jellicoe Road with a tragic accident that will have far reaching repercussions for each character in the novel. Then, abruptly, the story starts again twenty-two years later at the Jellicoe School--the boarding school located farther down the same road--when Taylor Markham is chosen to lead the school's faction in a secret territory war that has spanned a generation between the school boarders, the Townies, and the Cadets.The Jellicoe School is the only real home Taylor has ever known. She has been at the school since she was eleven, when her mother abandoned her on Jellicoe Road and Hannah drove by to pick Taylor up and take her to the school. Now seventeen, Taylor is in many ways still a young girl afraid of being abandoned by those she loves. Which is why, at the start of the story, Taylor balks at the authority thrust upon her and the relationships it will necessitate. Leading the Jellicoe School through the territory wars is bad enough, but being in charge of an entire dorm of students seems truly unbearable. Taylor's resolve to live a life apart is tested, and in many ways broken, with the efforts of well-meaning friends and the appearance of Jonah Griggs--the one person Taylor never expected to see, or need, ever again.As the territory wars escalate, Taylor's life is thrown into disarray with the sudden disappearance of Hannah--the only adult Taylor would come close to calling family. With Hannah gone, Taylor begins reading Hannah's unfinished novel for lack of anything else to cling to. Marchetta weaves Taylor's story and the events of Hannah's novel and even the histories of other characters together to create one haunting narrative where, the more Taylor reads, the more it feels like she is looking not at fictitious characters but at people she has known her entire life.While trying to understand Hannah's sudden absence, Taylor also starts to understand herself. Eventually she realizes that living life at a distance offers no protection from abandonment and provides even fewer options to heal scars from past betrayals.The novel starts with rapid fire narration as Taylor throws out events and names at the reader without any frame of reference. Later in the story the importance of the Cadet, the Hermit, and the Brigadier becomes painfully obvious. But in the first pages the narrative comes closer to painfully confusing and unwieldy. By the end of my reading I had a marker at almost every page to indicated important points and favorite passages. However, if you can roll with the uncertainty, you will be rewarded. At a little over four hundred pages, Marchetta still creates a page-turner that moves quickly and weaves together every single narrative thread by the final page.Because Taylor is not forthcoming with explanations, the novel reads like a mystery (fitting since my two Printz Award predictions were also mysteries of sorts). However a good portion of the story is also simply about friendship and love. Taylor expects neither from her time on the Jellicoe Road even though they might be exactly what she was supposed to find there all along. Marchetta blends moments of humor and gravitas in her unique prose style to create another really great read.* Jellicoe Road was actually originally published, I assume in Marchetta's native Australia, with the title On the Jellicoe Road. For various reasons, upon finishing the novel, I feel that this title is superior to the American edition's shortened version.** The book was originally published, again I assume in Australia, in 2006.*** In addition to the original title being superior, in terms of relevance to the story, the original cover art is also much more apt. (Although I just realized the US cover has a Poppy on it which I will grudgingly admit is actually pretty relevant to the story. It also makes it impossible to pick a cover to feature here so, readers, you get both.)
Had a hard time getting through this. Actually, I didn't. Got about 1/3 of the way. But I'll go back to this one again. I think I just was reading it at a bad time -- very tired.

Somewhere around halfway through Jellicoe Road Aaron asked me what my book was about and I responded, "...I'm still not really sure, actually."I spent the first 3/4 of the book totally puzzled and the last 1/4 bawling because: the love! the tragedy! the bittersweetness of it all!I was really annoyed for the first 150 pages because I don't like books that are all intentionally convoluted only to pull together at the last minute in an attempt to make you say, "Ah yes! Of course. How clever!" But this one pulled together so beautifully that I forgave it and declared my love for it and am now sorrowing that I must return it to the library. But that structure might make it difficult for readers who don't have the patience to wade through the (very long) confusing bits to get to the wonderful bits at the end. If you can make it, though, it's worth it!

Summary: At a boarding school in the Australian bush country, Taylor Markham has been selected as the reluctant leader to represent the school in negotiations with their rivals, the Townies and the Cadets. But when the only adult in her life disappears and Taylor finds out the Cadet leader knows her better than she’d like, will she be able to hold it together and protect her kids from retaliation?Review: When I finished Jellicoe Road, I smiled and set it down on my nightstand. Not 30 seconds later, I picked it back up and started reading it again from the beginning. The last time I did that was with the fourth Harry Potter. Actually, that might be the only other time I’ve ever done that.So yeah, I loved it.This is just from page 2, and there’s more where that came from, I promise. The narrator is talking about having survived a car crash where her parents were driving.Someone asked us later, “Didn’t you wonder why no one came across you sooner?”Did I wonder?When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know?Wonder dies.But don’t take that one snippet to mean this book is all depressing. It’s not at all. It’s heartbreaking, yes, but also hopeful. And funny.This is one of my all-time YA favorites.
Through the use of more tragedy and conflict than any one person is likely to experience in their lives, this book perfectly captures the intensity of being young and in love.
For the first forty pages I was really confused about what was going on. Then it was okay

I found the beginning of this book confusing and hard to get into, but after the first seventy pages or so, it sucked me in and it haunted me for a couple days after I finished. You know a book's written well, when it stays with you like that after you put it down. I just wish the beginning was easier to wade through.
By the end of this book I was really engrossed, but it took awhile. The interaction between the two stories was intriguing.

I can see why this won the Printz award this year. I really really liked this book. I was advised (not by people I know, but by bloggers) to stick with this one, even if the beginning frustrates you beyond all reason. And I was never really frustrated with the book, but I was confused. Especially at the beginning. The book starts out very much like a puzzle and I enjoyed putting the pieces together. There were a few things I had issues with : one, Taylor is hinted at being an unreliable narrator a few times, but it didn't really become an issue in the telling of the story - it wasn't a Catcher in the Rye kind of unreliable narrator sort of situation, but there were a few discrepancies between her story and the stories put forth by other characters. Might have just been me getting my panties in a bunch over nothing. The other thing (and this might be a big thing for some readers) is that I put the pieces together too soon. Before the narrator. In some cases many many pages before the narrator. While I do pride myself on being an expert reader, this bugs me. I feel like I shouldn't know something WAY before the main character does. I should maybe think...could that be? nah, there would have been more hints....not Oh I get it now. Wait....she doesn't? Seriously? So yeah. Other than those two points, I really liked this book. I liked that it was set in Australia, but there wasn't too much crazy slang that threw me off. And I liked the characters and the premise. Intriguing and new. Something different, but yet that dealt with contemporary issues. Two thumbs up.

It's a good read and nicely constructed, but the amount of barely contained emotion in this book made me tired after about 200 pages. The narrative voice is very cool and restrained, so it didn't quite veer off into melodrama, but sometimes I wished there had been more quiet and ordinary things going on in between the characters' intense revelations of family and personal history. And I got skeptical sometimes about all the caring being directed at Taylor. All the right people care about each other and seem much too emotionally fluent for people who have supposedly suffered so much damage throughout their lives. But it's a sweet story, if you're willing to suspend your disbelief a little. And the second to last page did give me chills, a bit.

Had to move on. I kept putting it down and picking it up again because it won the Printz this year, and the reviewers said it comes together really well. I love complex stories, generally, and want to see how Hannah's story comes together with Taylors. I love the Australian authors, and I loved Marchetta's Saving Francesca. So, this has a lot going for it, but I think I'm just not in the mood right now. Recommended for high school.

Although I really liked the last 1/4 of the book, it took me a long time to get into this book. I am sure I missed a lot of stuff at the beginning because I was confused. Perhaps if I read the book again I would like it more. I don't know many teens who would stick with this book...I think many would start it and never finish it. I'll have to read more reviews to figure out why it won the Printz!

Taylor Markham is a leader in a dorm in rural Australia where she plots little wars against the military cadets and townies who all share common territory around their schools. A simple teen story about growing up, family, friendships and first love runs parallel to the real tragedy and mystery that pervade Taylor’s world. We care and worry about her as she seeks to find answers about her mother, father and other family members whose lives were shattered on one sunny day many years before on Jellicoe Road. This is a complex and riveting tale recommended for mature teens and deserving of the Printz award even though I loved The Hunger Games!

The only reason I started reading this book is because it won the Printz Award for young adult literature. I had never even heard of the book when it won, but I moved it to the top of my "to read" list. I only finished the book because a fellow librarian told me "keep going, it's worth it." Most books that have a hook like this one, "My father took 132 minutes to die. I counted," keep you hooked, but the marvel of this book is in my ever changing experience as a reader. One page one I was hooked (if not a little disturbed by the subject matter). By page fifty I was bored and confused. By page 100 I was ready to put it down. Thank goodness I didn't. By page 150 I was reeling through it enraptured and excited as I connected the dots and the puzzle pieces slowly came into place. This book is a moving depiction of two generations as their lives run in near parallel. Taylor Markham discovers the truths she either never knew or didn't remember and comes to realizations about love and relationships. It sounds cheesy and cliche when I put it that way, but really the book is anything but cheesy and cliched. It's a bit hard to put your finger on and I don't want to give anything away so that the puzzle can come together for you, too. I can tell you that you'll find a teenage girl frantically grappling with the past, a relationship fueled as much by dislike as it is by a sense of connectedness and longing, a territory war among three factions and a patch of poppies along the side of the most beautiful road you'll ever see, Jellicoe Road.

Before reading this book I was told to stick with it past the first 200 pages and that it helps to go back and reread parts. I was afraid I would feel somewhat let down after high expectations. I was impressed by the way two stories 18 years apart intersected and had similarities and differences. I actually enjoyed going back and rereading parts after I had finished. It added to the experience of the book. Most of all, this book reminds us that great tragedies, great friendships, great loves, great joy can come from average, everyday situations and people.

Ick, puke. Just what I love to read. . . a book about more self-absorbed, overly introspective, egocentric overdramatic teenaged girls. My social worker and counselor friends almost universally had the same reaction. This art does not resemble real life. Give me some honest portrayals.

The beginning of this book was confusing, because you don't know who the people are and I personally didn't realize we were looking at 2 different time periods etc. Once I started piecing the puzzle together, I had a hard time putting it down. So...for those of you who are having a hard time with this one - just give it a little more time!

For the first several chapters, I was confused about just what was going on in this book. It took some work on my part, like looking back to previous chapters, before I eventually "got it." But the work was worth it, and I couldn't put it down! These characters are so well-drawn. They are real. They are.

This book was nothing like I expected, right from page one.First off, the whole concept of the territory wars made it seem like the book should be some sort of post-apocalyptic tale, but then with all the modern-day cultural references (sparingly) sprinkled in, I realized that it was actually a present-day story.The first half of the book was just a tangle of plot and unexplained relationships, both past and present, and it was very disconcerting to not have much of a clue what was going on. The second half really picked up, and the story started to make a bit of sense and finally at the end, the reward was well worth the wait.If I could rate the book in parts, I'd give the first half about three stars, the next quarter four stars, and the end four and a half to five. I guess that with all the confusion at the beginning, I wasn't AS caught up in the story as I could have been so the payoff at the end wasn't a solid five even though I did really enjoy it.I love stories that weave themselves together, making unrelated strands all have a clear place in the tale by the end. Holes is another really enjoyable example.I'd definitely read more of Melina Marchetta. One side note: I did find it interesting that the US version of this book is just called "Jellicoe Road" instead of "On the Jellicoe Road." I wonder why they bothered to change it? It's like changing Northern Lights to The Golden Compass - whyyy? If anyone is going to understand the Northern Lights reference it would be people in this hemisphere, right? Oh well.Read this if you can have some patience for a giant question-mark beginning, knowing that it will all be worth it. :)

This book took some time to get into (although it has one of the most intriguingly engaging first chapters I've ever encountered which made me keep reading.) Once the book started to pick up steam (I found the early chapters on the battle between the Townies, Cadets, and Jellicoe students kind of tedious) I was thoroughly hooked into the story and just started weeping when I reached the end, partly because the last 100 pages are truly beautiful, and partly because I was really sad to see the story end.

5Q 3P S“Jellicoe Road” was the surprise winner of the 2009 Michael L. Printz Award. Taylor Markham is the main character in this novel filled with mystery, emotion, tragedy, and love. Taylor must solve the puzzle of her past, and make the necessary connections to the present, in order to ensure her future. All the while she is coping with being head of her boarding school dorm, and finds herself representing her school in the territorial war with the Townies and the Cadets. Further complications ensue when she discovers that the Cadets are lead by Jonah Griggs, another part of her past she can’t seem to leave behind. The truth all comes to light on the Jellicoe Road, “the prettiest road I’ve ever seen…”. Developmentally the book delves into teenage peer relationships, the importance of family and one’s past, and the ultimate need for love and to belong (versus abandonment, etc.). The book is full of mystery, adventure, and surprising twists and turns that have definite young adult appeal. The only problem is that the novel is quite confusing in the beginning, going between Taylor in the present and Hannah’s manuscript of the past. I must admit that it is difficult to get into the novel initially, and I’m not sure if young adults will read far enough into the story to get hooked. I would promote the book with other award winners, taking the opportunity to educate teens on the various awards and honors available to young adult literature.

This book is going to haunt me. So exquisitely painful. And beautifully hopeful. And achingly sad. I couldn't put it down. And now I'll need to read something absolutely mindless and fluffy and stupid in an attempt to get certain images out of my head long enough for me to sleep. But even if that doesn't work, it was worth it!

I have had this book for a week and I am only on Chapter 3. It's sort of painful right now and I am considering ditching it. Someone, tell me if I should keep going.Ok so now I'm done and although I can't say anything negative about it (interesting characters, exciting and surprising plot, original setting) I just wasn't wowed personally. I think it was all the territory wars, which I tried really hard to care about since it made sense to me why territory was so important to these kids, but I just couldn't care enough. It's akin to how I feel about the game Risk. I appreciate the game and understand why it's so popular, but do I want to play? Not really.I will be recommending this book a lot, though. I think it will rock a lot of folks' socks.
Although slow to begin, I found myself invested in the lives of Taylor and her 'family'.

I'm a sucker for books with links to the past, strong bonds of family and friendship, and hope intermingled with tragedy. Jellicoe Road has it all- I cried, I laughed, I cried some more. The satisfaction I had at the end reminded me how I felt when reading Harry Potter and all the pieces about his parents, Syrius, and the Marauders Map came together... I love that!
